profileText: A Senator from Arizona; born in Winnemucca, Humboldt County, Nev., September 13, 1874; moved with his parents to Arizona in 1875 and settled near the present town of Flagstaff, Coconino County; attended the public schools of Flagstaff and graduated from the Stockton (Calif.) Business College in 1896; studied law and political economy at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor; admitted to the bar in 1897 and commenced practice in Williams, Ariz.; member of the Territorial house of representatives in 1897 and 1899, serving as speaker in 1899; served in the Territorial senate in 1903; district attorney of Coconino County 1905-1908; moved to Prescott, Ariz. in 1909 and continued the practice of law; upon the admission of Arizona as a State was elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate on March 27, 1912; reelected in 1916, 1922, 1928, and again in 1934, and served from March 27, 1912, to January 3, 1941; unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1940; chairman, Committee on Indian Affairs (Sixty-third through Sixty-fifth Congresses), Committee on Industrial Expositions (Sixty-third Congress), Committee to Investigate Trespassers on Indian Land (Sixty-sixth Congress), Committee on the Judiciary (Seventy-third through Seventy-sixth Congresses); appointed a member of the Board of Immigration Appeals in the Department of Justice on April 8, 1941, and served until February 28, 1943, when he retired; died in Washington, D.C., May 31, 1962; interment in Sacred Heart Cemetery, Prescott, Ariz.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Ashurst, Henry F. A Many-Colored Toga: The Diary of Henry Fountain Ashurst. Edited by George F. Sparks. Tucson: University of Arizona Press, 1962.
___. Speeches of Henry Fountain Ashurst of Arizona. Phoenix: Sen. Barry Goldwater, 1956.

___. "Three Years of the Diary of Henry Fountain Ashurst, 1910-1913.'' Introductory essay by George F. Sparks; annotations by Herman E. Bateman and Ray Brandes. Arizona and the West 3 (Spring 1961): 7-38.
___. Up in Coconino County: Pages from the Journal of Henry Fountain Ashurst. Edited by Grant Dahlstrom. Pasdena: Castle Press, 1957.
Cognac, Robert Earl. "The Senatorial Career of Henry Fountain Ashurst.'' Master's thesis, Arizona State University, 1953.
Schlup, Leonard. "The Silver-Tongued Clarion Sunbeam from Coconino County: Henry F. Ashurst and the League of Nations." Nanzan Review of American Studies 16 (1994): 56-68.
Sparks, George F. "The Speaking of Henry Fountain Ashurst.'' Ph.D. dissertation, University of Utah, 1953.

researchRecord.name: In the Frank Murphy papers, 1908-1949. Finding aid.

1904-1940. 10 inches. Includes copies of Congressional Record, Senate executive documents, copies of bills he introduced, campaign material, clippings, and business correspondence. Also miscellaneous letters in various other collections including Benjamin Julius McKinney papers, 1863-1964; and Thomas Maddock papers, 1917-1965.

Photostat copies of correspondence, reprints of speeches, remarks, articles and reports (1910-1962); in the George P. Hunt collection, 1709-1955; the Henry Stanley McClusky papers, 1908-1963 (bulk 1916-1930); and the William Plato Stuart family papers, 1903-1967 (bulk 1925-1956). Finding aid.
1900-1960. .25 foot. Correspondence, speeches, and clippings relating to the removal of the Ashurst cabin to the Pioneer Arizona Museum in Phoenix.
Correspondence (1912-1960) and a speech (1946) in James A. Pitts papers, 1912-1960.

1896-1962 (bulk 1912-1962). 7 boxes, 1 volume, 2 portfolios. Correspondence, typescripts of speeches, campaign expense records, cartoons, scrapbooks, reprints, and photographs. Majority of letters relate to the U.S. Senate election of 1940. Finding aid.
